content.question: In a region of Africa where malaria is common, <math alttext="9%" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>9</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of the population is born with a severe form of sickle-cell anemia (<math alttext="Lowercase s lowercase s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="italic">ss</mtext></math>). Carriers of the sickle-cell allele (heterozygotes) are resistant to malaria and display only mild symptoms of malaria if exposed to the malaria parasite. If an effective antimalarial program is instituted in the region, which of the following is most likely to occur over many generations?

choices.label: The frequency of the sickle-cell allele will increase, as there will be more heterozygous individuals.
The incidence of malaria will decrease, but the incidence of sickle-cell anemia will increase.

The frequency of the sickle-cell allele <math alttext="Lowercase s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="italic">s</mtext></math> will decrease as the incidence of malaria decreases.
The frequency of the sickle-cell allele will increase because antimalarial treatments cause mutations.

content.answer: The frequency of the sickle-cell allele <math alttext="Lowercase s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext mathvariant="italic">s</mtext></math> will decrease as the incidence of malaria decreases.
